Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Partial Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Each summer from 2014 to 2016, 9 undergraduate students will participate in an 8 week summer REU Site on Partial Differential Equations and Dynamical Systems held at the Florida Institute of Technology Mathematical Sciences Department. It will be directed by Principal Investigator Ugur Abdulla and two faculty members, and assisted by three graduate students. The REU Site is designed to involve undergraduate students in innovative research in nonlinear partial differential equations, optimal control and inverse problems for systems with distributed parameters, and dynamical systems and chaos theory, while utilizing modern tools of mathematical and numerical analysis. Students will have a great opportunity to pursue hands-on, original research on the frontier of modern mathematics, which will include the evolution of interfaces for nonlinear reaction-diffusion-convection equations, inverse free boundary problems and optimal control of phase transition processes, and the fine classification of minimal periodic orbits of discrete dynamical systems with application in chaos theory.

The REU aims to train a new generation of well-rounded mathematicians to shed light on the mathematical problems which arise by modeling complex real life problems, and attacking them with the complementary tools of theoretical and numerical analysis. At least half of the students will be recruited from underrepresented groups and from colleges with restricted research opportunities. Students will work in three groups of three undergraduates, along with the PI and one or two other faculty mentors, and one graduate mentor. Each group will work on a cutting edge research problem with potential opportunities of new discoveries in the field. All the students will be prepared to present their research results in national conferences and to publish research papers in high level mathematical journals. The REU Site will facilitate a transition from undergraduate to graduate studies in research careers and inform students about job opportunities that are at the intersection of applied mathematics and STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site at the Florida Institute of Technology is designed to involve undergraduate students in innovative research in nonlinear partial differential equations, optimal control and inverse problems for systems with distributed parameters, dynamical  systems, and chaos theory. 29 undergraduate students representing 24 universities from 18 states and Puerto Rico attended the REU program for eight weeks during the months of June and July over four years, from 2014-2017. The REU site was directed and supervised by Principal Investigator (PI) Ugur G. Abdulla and four faculty members, and assisted by six PhD students. Students pursued hands-on, original research on the frontier of modern mathematics, including the evolution of interfaces for nonlinear reaction-diffusion-convection equations, inverse free boundary problems and optimal control of phase transition processes, and the fine classification of minimal periodic orbits of discrete dynamical systems with application in chaos theory.

Significant advancement of the boundary of mathematical knowledge was achieved as a result of FIT REU research in 2014-2017. 

Four research papers have been published, one is accepted for publication, and one is currently in the review process, all in top mathematical journals with high impact factor. Three more research papers are in preparation. 11 REU projects were presented at the prestigious NSF-funded Young Mathematicians Conference (YMC 2014-2017) at Ohio State University. 26 students were invited presenters at 4 YMCs. REU students presented 15 lectures in three Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM 2015-2017), REU Symposium at NSF organized by Undergraduate Research Council, SIAM Conference on Analysis of PDEs in 2015, AMS Southeastern regional meeting in Orlando in 2017.

The REU Site trained a new generation of well-rounded mathematicians to shed light on the mathematical problems which arise by modeling complex real life problems, and attacking them with the complementary tools of theoretical and numerical analysis. The REU Site facilitated a transition from undergraduate to graduate studies in research careers and informed students about job opportunities that are at the intersection of applied mathematics and STEM disciplines. REU Site organized professional development opportunities for students such as skype meetings with graduate directors of top US Universities, developing skills to communicate scientific research to professional audiences, activities on scientific ethics, meetings with NASA astronauts, trips to Salvador Dali museum and Kennedy Space Center.

The REU site created a continuous flow of students to top PhD programs in the US specializing in Analysis and PDEs. 60% of students are attending PhD programs at top schools in the US. 47% of these students are women. One REU student was awarded with an NSF Graduate Fellowship and accepted to the PhD program in Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. One other female REU student received Honorable Mention for NSF Graduate Fellowship, and is attending a PhD program at the University of Arizona. One high school student who attended REU Site for three successive summers won first place and grand award in Mathematics Category and was awarded with Dudley R. Herschbach SIYSS award in Intel ISEF 2018, May 13-16, Pittsburgh, PA. This award will provide a full expense-paid trip to attend and present his research in the Stockholm International Youth Science Seminar during the Nobel Prize Ceremonies in December 2018. 25% of REU students are working in Industry. 41% of REU students were women. 60% of REU students were either women, minorities, or representing four year schools with limited research opportunities. 

PI created Mathematical Blog at http://reu.fit.edu/blog/ to help REU students, and currently blog is serving mathematical community worldwide.

Publications produced as a result of REU Research:

1. Ugur G. Abdulla, Jonathan Goldfarb, Evan Cosgrove, On the Frechet Differentiability in Optimal Control of Coefficients in Parabolic Free Boundary Problems, Evolution Equations and Control Theory, 6, 2017, 317-344.

2. Ugur G. Abdulla, Rashad Abdulla, Muhammad Abdulla, Naveed Iqbal, Second Minimal Orbits, Sharkovski Ordering and Universality in Chaos, International Journal of Bifurcation and Chaos, 27, 2017, 1-24.

3. Ugur G. Abdulla, Jonathan Goldfarb, Frechet differentiability in Besov spaces in the optimal control of parabolic free boundary problems, Inverse and Ill-Posed Problems, 26, 2(2017), 211-228.

4. Ugur G. Abdulla, Bruno Poggi, Optimal Control of the Multiphase Stefan Problem, Applied Mathematics and Optimization, 77, 2018.

5. Ugur G. Abdulla, Jian Du, Adam Prinkey, Chloe Ondracek, Suneil Parimoo, Evolution of Interfaces for the Nonlinear Double Degenerate Parabolic Equation of Turbulent Filtration with Absorption, Mathematics and Computers in Simulation, 2018.
